sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Villain, leave fooling.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: There's none in the caſe, ſir—She never did wiſer—had ſhe ſtaid your return, ſhe had fallen into thoſe clutches which will immediately gripe you, if you don't make off; Roſa has ran, till ſhe had little breath left, to tell you the corregidor and alguazils are coming to apprehend all in this houſe—ſo ſave yourſelf, ſir—ſhe's ſafe enough—Antonio has taken her to a nunnery.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A nunnery, ſlave!—there ſhe's loſt to me for ever—When once they are inform'd of theſe tranſactions—

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: Be pacified, ſir, it was ſo deſign'd, at firſt.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: But mym aſter has convey'd her, ſir, to his brother-in-law's, whoſe credit and quality are ſo eminent, that the engaging him in your mutual protection, he doubts not, will much avail you—My maſter's bride, too, will aſſiſt to comfort her—I was ordered to wait o'purpoſe to inform you this; and if you will venture to follow them, to aſſure you, you may depend on a protection there alſo. I have the key of my maſter's apartments to conduct you privately; and he intreats you will go in a chair, to avoid being queſtion'd, in caſe of any encounter by the way.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: My noble friend! with gratitude I embrace his counſel.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Hollo! up with your burden, beaſts, and fall into your half trot [the chair brought, Florio gets into it]

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: Heavens! we are all taken! ſit ſtill, ſir, for your life.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: We have them ſafe.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: You find, ſir, I was right.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Some of you ſearch the houſe throughout: ſee what ſervants there are beſide thoſe in the hall. Be quick—we wait you here

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: This is one of Don Cupid's pretty jeſts: we are ſtruck upon a rock before we put out to ſea.—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What are you, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: A creature very like a man, ſir, only I want a heart.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You're pleaſant, ſir—Pray Heav'n your mirth continue!—Who is that woman veil'd?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Let her anſwer for herſelf, if your worſhip pleaſes—She has a tongue; ſet it once a going, and ſhe'll tell more than ſhe knows.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Uncover her face.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: [to the Alguazil] Hold, friend!—Couſin, conſider, ſhould it be Honoria, 'twould be terrible to expoſe her here.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis juſt—go, then, and ſpeak in private to her.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: [to Juan, addreſſing her] 'Tis I, ſir, Roſa, attending on my lady; I was commanded by her—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Enough; I underſtand the reſt, and pity her: bid her ſit ſtill; I'll do my beſt to ſave her from diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: A lucky miſtake: it may ſave Florio from the officers. [Goes to the chair] They take you, for my miſtreſs, ſir, ſit cloſe; I'll follow, and watch all occaſions for your eſcape.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: We have found our wandering nymph, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Was that Honoria?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: No, ſir; her waiting-woman Roſa, following the chair wherein they were conveying Honoria to ſome other place.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: We arrived luckily—had we ſtaid a moment longer, they had all been fled.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Alg.
sp.p: Should we ſee who's in the chair, ſir?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No, forbear; the folly is puniſhment enough to a woman of her rank, without adding that of public diſgrace—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: How ſingularly happy it was, that you perſuaded Don Henriquez to expect us at your houſe!—Had he been a witneſs to this diſcovery, his fury had tranſgreſſed all bounds.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis true; and matters of this fort had better be reconciled by the mediation of friends, than either private reſentments, or public trials—Who do you belong to, friend?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: To nobody.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Do not you ſerve?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: I did; but my maſter has loſt himſelf—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Take his ſword.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Pardon me, ſir—I will ſurrender it.—I cou'd not bear to be diſarm'd by any hand but my own;—This is a weapon, I'd have you to know, of ſuch dreadful execution, that I dare not draw it, but at the call of juſtice.—Sir, as ſoon as you reach home, pleaſe to hang it up in your hall, and write under it,
sp.l: This is bold Guzman's ſword; O may it be
Ever from ruſt, as 'tis from ſlaughter free!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Thou'rt a pleaſant fellow.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p:
Faith, ſir, I never make myſelf uneaſy for love, riches, or reputation—nor do I pretend to that great ſublety of ſenſe, to feel before I am
hurt; and, for the moſt part, I keep out of harm's way—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: This fellow's an original.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: But of ſo ill a hand, ſir, I am not worth hanging up among the worſt of your worſhip's collection.
sp.stage: Enter Alguazils, with two Men and two Women Servants.

sp.speaker: 2d Alg.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your worſhip, we ſearch'd the ho • ſe from the cellar to the garrets, and theſe are all of the family to be found.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Theſe are moſt material—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Take ſpecial care of this varlet, and the waiting-woman; we'll have the truth from them I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: Muſt we be priſoners together, Guzman?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: It's not ſo bad as the bands of wedlock, Roſa.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Hold! On reflection, we had better not carry Honoria home, till her brother's fury is abated; therefore, if you approve it, couſin, I'll take her to my houſe; as it is our deſire to compoſe this buſineſs quietly, ſhe will be in a kinſman's houſe with more decency and ſatisfaction, and will have, beſide, my ſiſter to accompany her; and further—

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: A lovely damſel they are bearing off!—ſome what hairy, 'tis true, about the chin, but that's a ſign of ſtrength. It tickles me to think how like an aſs his worſhip will look, when he opens the ſhell, to find ſo rough a kernel.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And the lights too?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p:
Yes, and your officers—take them all off. I have two of Don Henriquez's ſervants; we ſhall be enough to guard our priſoners, and darkneſs will ſuit us beſt. The more privacy, the
ſafer will Honoria's reputation be. Couſin, good night.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You propoſe well, ſir—this buſineſs could not be in better hands than your's—There I'll leave it, and wiſh you a good night.—Officers, follow me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: You may go about your buſineſs, friends; I require none but theſe. Take up the chair, and follow theſe your guides.
sp.stage: Scene changes to Honoria's Anti-chamber, in Henriquez's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now that we are ſafely arriv'd within theſe walls, madam, diſmiſs your fears; pleaſe to remain here till I bring lights, and acquaint Honoria with the happineſs ſhe will receive in entertaining ſo fair a gueſt.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Acquaint whom, ſir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My wife Honoria—a little patience—ſhe will attend you.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Is her name Honoria, too? Heaven preſerve her from ſuch diſtreſſes as attend her nameſake!—But where am I? ſo far from gueſſing the houſe, that, what with my fears, and darkneſs of the night, I can't conceive what quarter of the town it is: then we have taken ſo many turnings to avoid meeting my cruel brother, and his train;—but I truſt in providence, I am now in a place out of his reach.
sp.stage: Enter ANTONIO with Lights; ſets them on the Table.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I now go, madam, to fetch my wife; your pardon a moment.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
And if, as this friendly man flatters me,
I can but conciliate a friendſhip here—Save me! my brother's houſe!—this is the quarter joining to my own apartment—I cannot be miſtaken—This the patronage and ſarety I was promis'd!—falſe, falſe man—Yet to what end?—Why ſhould he betray me? My Florio cou'd not mean—Oh, no, let me not think it—but that this man, who look'd like truth itſelf! to whom my Florio thought he could entruſt his happineſs and life—that he ſhould be ſo baſe, to throw me into that danger it was my only care to ſhun!—All's over now—Struggling and hope alike are vain, and all my future life is miſery.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Who can this lady be?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is, I confeſs, madam, a liberty, which I perhaps ought not to take ſo early, but the diſtreſs of her ſituation will beſt apologize to your generous heart—The lady—but ſhe can beſt relate her ſtory; I will go ſeek Don Henriquez, and engage his power and intereſt in her behalf.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Madam, I—Heavn's—Honoria! Stay, ſtay Antonio—it is not fit Henriquez ſhould be told—he's gone, and we are undone.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Antonio, ſaid you couſin? what mean you?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Unlucky girl! you are fallen into your huſband's hands—I have made ſuch diſcoveries—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: O Heaven's!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: This is the man, to whom you are contracted; and, to aggravate our perplexities, the very hero, who preſerv'd my life, and honour; tho', I begin to fear, at the expence of my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
His behaviour, and motives, then are well explain'd—The man, to whom I was engag'd, has been a witneſs to my concealment, my ſhame—my paſſion for another—and he has uſed this means
to bring me to my abandon'd home, that he and my unnatural brother, may wreak their cruel vengeance on me.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I am all amazement—How came you into his hands?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: My Florio, to whom he proves an intimate friend, entruſted me to his care; tho' till this moment, I never heard his name;—that might have alarm'd me—but every ſlighteſt circumſtance concurs to ruin me.—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: But were you diſtracted, to let him bring you here, or blind, not to know your own houſe?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: How could I in ſuch darkneſs, ſuch fear, ſuch confuſion? beſide, he brought me in the back way, thro' his own quarter, and had the lights put out, before he introduc'd me—Well, I am prepar'd to ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Not in ſuch haſte, my dear girl—while there is life there is hope—I'll ſtruggle to the laſt moment—Don't you remember the miſtake Antonio's ſervant made this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Antonio' has done the ſame, in your abſence; and, on your account, I did not diſabuſe him. He has renew'd his vows of love with equal ardour, as when he firſt ſaw me, and ſeem'd tranſported to diſcover his deſtin'd wife in the woman whom he reſcued. There hangs your hope, and mine.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Vain ſuggeſtion! What hope can we have, while this cruel contract remains ſuch a bar to our general happineſs?—Beſides, he has ſeen my brother by this time—the whole is out—and ruin certain.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Not ſo very certain, as you apprehend. Antonio's friendſhip to Florio, which induc'd him to-protect you, may yet—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p:
Friendſhip! dear Felicia, will that remain unſhaken?—will that ſtand up againſt theſe ſtrange
events?—againſt the affront done to his honour? Oh! no—He is not what he was,—his mind, his principles are changed, and I am made the victim to his wrath—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Antonio change! It is impoſſible. Tho' all felicity this world affords ſhould bribe him, it could not tempt him to recede from his pledg'd faith, and honour.—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I forgot her intereſt in him.—Pardon me, my dear Felicia. I ſcarce know what I ſay. My mind is wounded by the variety of my afflictions.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My lovely girl!—excuſe my warmth—but I muſt repeat my aſſertions—If we have yet a chance for happineſs, 'tis founded in his ſteadineſs and truth—The more I contemplate it, the more do my ſpirits and hopes revive. If you cou'd ſecure yourſelf from your brother, this night only, what between my hero and brother—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: But where ſecure myſelf?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Steal home with me.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: By the ſecret door, thro' which you have ſo often paſs'd, to meet your Florio—when laſt we uſed it, it was fatal; now it may be fortunate. Once eſcaped, get my brother's aſſent for this night's concealment, and aſk his further advice, and aſſiſtance. I'll anſwer for him; he is generous, and kind—My lover brave and wiſe—dry your eyes; O'my credit, you ſhall not weep, till you have more occaſion.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: He's here again, couſin.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Suppoſe we undeceive him—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Undeceive him!—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Yes—ſuch a confidence, I am ſure, muſt rivet him to our intereſts.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, be cautious. I yet have doubts of his conduct.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I have none. Our hopes in him will be made certainties hereby.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: You'll infallibly repent it—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not yet return'd!—A gueſt in his houſe too, that's come ſo far on ſuch a buſineſs! ſomething I can't comprehend—I have not yet been able, madam, to find your brother; but think it can't be long e'er he returns; then I'll inform him of the accident, which has made his houſe this lady's ſanctuary.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: He perſiſts in his miſtake, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: 'Tis now time, Don Antonio, to inform you—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I cou'd not wait at the corregidor's, tho' I promiſed; my impatience to unfold this riddle burns me up—that Don Antonio ſhould entertain my ſiſter when I was poſitive—By heav'n ſhe's there, and Felicia with her!—were all my raſcals mad, or was it a plot to inſult me? and Don Juan! was he mad too? to ſwear he had trac'd her to another houſe? either I, or they, or all, muſt be poſſeſs'd—Some enchantment reigns here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here is Don Henriquez—now I'll inform him, madam, of your ſad ſtory.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Undone utterly!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Don Henriquez—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I ſhall ſink.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This lady, with your ſiſter Honoria—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I know her well, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then you will the eaſier excuſe my boldneſs.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: In what, ſir?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Now it comes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That I have been the occaſion of your finding her here, at this late hour.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I underſtand you, ſir; ſhe is deſirous to paſs this night, with Honoria, and aſſiſt her in ordering her nuptial ceremonies.—Ay, in heav'n's name, let her ſtay.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Better than I expected. Courage cuz!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But, ſir, the neceſſity, that induces me to—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Dear ſir, can you ſuppoſe an apology neceſſary for Honoria, and her kinſwoman, paſſing a night together?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is ſhe ſo near a relation of his? 'tis well I told no more of her ſtory.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: She knows, I owe her for many favours, and hope to be able to repay them amply.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: There—can he ſpeak his deſign much plainer?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: For that matter, the cap would fit me, as well as you.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Since it is ſo late, ſir, will you give the ladies leave to retire, for the preſent, to their own chamber? withdraw, Honoria.—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Now Felicia!—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I don't like this ſudden calm—'tis but the fore-runner of another ſtorm; let us fly to ſhelter.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: But how, while they remain in the Aſide. room, thro' which we muſt paſs?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: We muſt watch their departure—'tis probable, he'll wait on Antonio to his apartment, and we may take that opportunity to eſcape.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will now go ſee whether Sancho has yet brought Florio to my apartment. Aſide. your pardon, ſir, I will but ſtep to my own chamber, and return immediately.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Shall I conduct you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know the way, I thank you, ſir.—[There's ſomething ſtrange in his words, and behaviour, which indicates diſguiſe and artifice. I muſt ſee it expounded.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: All the feinds in hell, ſure, cou'd not conjure up ſuch another myſtery. Juan affirms the people, we fought with, had convey'd Honoria away—when I come to ſeek her, at home, ſhe's miſſing, and her waiting wench tells me ſhe went into the garden, whence no one knows of her return. Antonio, juſt after, proteſts he ſaw, and entertain'd her in her own apartment, where I certainly now find her, and that ungrateful woman with her.—Theſe are riddles to poſe an Oedipus, and madden a ſtoick—They muſt be explain'd, and ſhall—Yet hold! Antonio ſaid he would return forthwith—here will I wait, 'till he arrives; ſee him ſafe at reſt, and then extort the whole truth from Honoria.—Could I but be convinced my honour were yet unſtain'd, I ſhould, I think, be ſomewhat eaſier. The load might be a little lighter, that's all I'm to expect;
No hope of perfect, or of laſting reſt,
While unrequited love corrodes the breaſt.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter JAQUES, with GUZMAN, ROSA, and FLORIO in the Chair.

sp.speaker: JAQUES.
sp.p: DAME Roſa, and brother ſervitor, in there; and now, my friends, open the chair, and let the lady out.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: By the darkneſs, this is the condemn'd dungeon, and when we are led out, it will be to execution.

sp.speaker: Jaques.
sp.p: Away, friends; you ſhall be paid below.
sp.stage: [Exit with the Chair, and locks the Door.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.p: What miſerable den am I thruſt into?—Roſa—Guzman—

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: I'm here, ſir—and Roſa cloſe to me, or I have loſt my ſenſe of feeling—one drop juſt to keep up my ſpirits—

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: Booby!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I can't conjecture where we are; I did not 〈◊〉 look out; but whereſoe'er, 'tis better than in the corregidor's hands.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: I am as much at a loſs as you, ſir—the moon clouding, and our quick pace prevented my obſerving the turnings.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: I wiſh they wou'd give us a little light, that we might ſee whether there was any means of running away, or no. I ſpy a glimmering under the door; the key turns—I'll venture to ſecure the candle however.
sp.stage: [He gets on one ſide of the door—Jaques entering with a candle, he ſeizes it.

sp.speaker: Jaques.
sp.p: Don Florio!
sp.stage: [Jaques ſeeing Florio, ſtarts, runs off quick, and double-locks the door.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: We're faſt again; we've got a light however, and may ſee what kind of place we are in!

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Thanks to Don Guzman! I always held ſtratagem in war, preferable to force.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: As I live, ſir, we are in Don Juan's houſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: I'm ſure, ſir; I have frequented it too often, on Cupid's errands, when you and my miſtreſs us'd to meet in Donna Felicia's apartment, to be miſtaken in any part of it.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: 'Tis too truly ſo; our enemies will ſoon know whom they have entangled in their ſnares, and then their malicious deſigns will be compleated.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: Stay, I think we have ſome room to hope—beyond that inner chamber, there is a backſtair-caſe, if the door be but open; it always us'd—let's try, ſir.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Lead on, guide.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p:
Not yet retunr'd! what an irkſome ſituation to a man of my anxious diſpoſition! in momentary expectation of Antonio, therefore not daring to enquire into what ſo intimately concerns my peace and honour; no, I muſt not attempt an explanation with my ſiſter, 'till the houſe be quiet, and Antonio retir'd to reſt. Shou'd he overhear any part of it, he wou'd reject her hand with ſcorn.—What ſtrange circumſtances have join'd together to prevent that ſingle and only event, which might give
me eaſe!—their marriage—'tis one comfort however, that I have her ſafe now; I have not quitted theſe apartments; ſhe cannot have made a ſecond garden-excurſion—Therefore, till I can ſettle the whole affair to my wiſhes, I will endeavour to ſubdue my temper, controul my feelings, and be no more under the dominion of ſuch paſſions, as rend my heart.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Why wou'd Don Henriquez leave the corregidor's, before I—Oh! he's here,—yet how ſhall I tell it him? Don Henriquez—I—I—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What, Don Juan? Why this heſitation?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I dread to tell the iſſue of our ſearch.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: You need not, my friend; ſome favourable circumſtances, and a little cool reflection, I truſt, have render'd me more temperate.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I ſhou'd rejoice to prove it: but when you have heard my ſtory, I fear you will relapſe.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Couſin, I've ſaid it—I will not—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: The corregidor and myſelf juſt reach'd the appointed place, time enough for his officers to ſeize the ſervants, who were accomplices, when they were juſt going to convey away in a chair—I cannot ſpeak it—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Out with it, man—conveying away whom?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Even ſo.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Oh! ho! ho! ho!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Do you laugh, couſin? You are indeed chang'd in temper when the honour of our family is a ſubject for your mirth.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Honoria! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: This is a worſe extreme, methinks, than t'other; your ſenſes are unſettled.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: You're not in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I am—I found her there, as ſure as you have life.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Why 'tis not poſſible—Antonio entertain'd Honoria here, even now, accompanied by your ſiſter; and even now I left them within, ſent her to her chamber myſelf.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Couſin, couſin, what motive can you have for endeavouring to impoſe on me? I tell you poſitively I found her there, and her waiting-woman Roſa with her.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Couſin, couſin, do not perſiſt thus to affirm impoſſibilities.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Sure you are making ſome experiment on my temper; are endeavouring to provoke me to one of your own frantick fits, that I may never dare to counſel you again; I ſwear to you, upon my honour, 'tis not half an hour ſince I left Honoria bearing away in a chair from the houſe, to which I dogg'd her, and your man Jaques leading the way, and guarding Roſa.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: And I ſwear to you, upon my honour, and the honour of our whole anceſtry, 'tis not a quarter of an hour, ſince I ſpoke with Honoria, and your ſiſter, in this very apartment.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Indeed, Don Henriquez—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: It may be decided this moment; follow me to her.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: O! ſir, I have ſuch admirable news, yet am ſo full of aſtoniſhment, I ſcarce have power to tell you.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Villain, diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: When I had convey'd madam Honoria—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: See! I told you ſo—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Roſa, and the man-ſervant who was with them, to your houſe, I lock'd 'em all three into your antichamber, and went down for a light.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: This madneſs is infectious, and my varlet is in one of Juan's fits.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: With which when I return'd, who ſhou'd I ſee, but Don Florio in the middle of the room, and madam Honoria vaniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: How is that poſſible, if you are ſure you lock'd the door, when you went to fetch candles?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Ay, that's the very point, ſir; that I can't tell—but—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: No matter, you are ſure you have Florio there?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: I'll forfeit my life on that, ſir.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: My injuries rekindle at his name; this moment will I ſacrifice the author of my ſhame, and inquietude.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Is then your promis'd coolneſs—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Away; I will not be advis'd, nor controul'd: the beaſt is in the toil, and he ſhall die.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who is the unhappy man, brother, you ſo ſeverely doom? And what the great offence to honour, which life alone can anſwer?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Sir—I—I—I am a villain if I know what to ſay to him;—how ſpiteful is his coming at this moment!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: His appearance juſt now is critically happy; I may, by his aid, aſſuage, at leaſt, if not o'er-rule this madneſs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Conſider me already as a friend, and brother, and as ſuch treat me; give me a knowledge of your wrongs—I have a ſword ready to ſerve in all occaſions worthy yourſelf and me.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: This affair, ſir, is ſo unfit—ſo unluckily tim'd, and your arrival here—it makes—how ſhall I ſhake him off?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Noble Don Antonio, if you value your brother's honour, perſiſt in accompanying him; I have moſt weighty reaſons, which when you know, you cannot but approve.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Wrong me not, Don Henriquez, by ſuſpicion: prove, by this early trial of my truth, how heartily I mean, thro' life, to eſpouſe the happineſs, and intereſts of your family.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I cannot doubt your honour, bravery, or attachment to our houſe; but, to engage ſo dear a gueſt in any cauſe of danger were inhoſpitable.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be what it may, let me partake it; you are too noble to employ your ſword in an unworthy cauſe; therefore I muſt, I will attend you, or you, by your diſtruſt, prevent our promis'd union.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Not knowing, ſir, the nature of thoſe injuries, whereon my reſentments are grounded, you may perhaps wonder at my deſperate meaſures.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are too good a judge of honour's dues, to purſue ſuch meaſures, as will not bear a friend's inſpection.—We go, ſir——

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: To witneſs my revenge—Lights there.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Sir, ſuffer him not to quit your ſight, I beg: and uſe all means to calm his rage; I'll follow inſtantly. [Exit Ant.] Let me reflect a moment;—if Honoria be there (as ſure ſhe muſt) heaven knows to what extremes Henriquez may be driven!—Florio, at leaſt, is there, and I have ignorantly been the means of throwing him into his enemy's power; 'tis therefore incumbent on me, while he has the ſanction of my houſe, to endeavour to preſerve his life, tho' at the hazard of my own.

div.stage: SCENE, the Chamber in Don JUAN's Houſe.
FLORIO, ROSA, and GUZMAN diſcover'd: Chairs, Table, and the Candle.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How thwart and provoking?

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: That unlucky door!—I never knew it ſhut before.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We have now no means, Roſa; my dangers and diſtreſſes are compleat! I muſt welcome and endure them. Yet ſhall not my deſperate ſtate make me neglect the only duty I can pay;—the amiable, the generous Felicia's reputation muſt not be left in doubt, even with the baſe Henriquez, whoſe cruel temper has form'd ſuſpicions unworthy of her blameleſs conduct; 'tis fit I ſet him right.
sp.stage: [Sits down to write in his Tablets.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: A curſe on all love! and a double curſe on all conſtant love! 'tis always attended with fatal diſaſters! or ends in the worſt of all, marriage.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you wiſh every body to have ſuch a quickſilver heart, as yours: that can ſettle no where.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Why, that wou'd not be amiſs for you, my dear Roſa; you might then hope to have your turn, as well as pretty fac'd damſels.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: And you wou'd be one of the laſt, I ſhou'd hear of; yet 'tis poſſible you might come, before you were welcome.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p:
She has wit, and good humour; excellent ingredients to paſs away time; I have a liking to her perſon too, but that will end with marriage, and poſſibly her good humour too;—well, honeſt Guzman, I wou'd adviſe you to be wary; if you ſhou'd couple yourſelf to a yoke, inſtead of a yokefellow, you'll wear it to your grave.
Yet, on recollection, your dancing days are now over; your pleaſures are come up to your mouth, you are now for the comfortable joys of life, eaſe, and eating. And there's no cook or dry-nurſe like a wife.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Roſa, ſhou'd aught but well befal me, give theſe with care to Don Henriquez' hands—either on his deſperate arm, or his black teſtimony at the bar, my life depends; no matter which way 'tis decided.
sp.stage: Enter HONORIA, and FELICIA, thro' a private Door.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I think no creature ſaw us paſs thro' the apartments.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What a tedious while have we been kept, before they left the chamber! My Florio too! what is become of him? The rage, we perceiv'd even now my brother to be in, makes me tremble, leſt, by ſome ſtrange means, he, as well as myſelf, may be thrown into his power.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: My deareſt miſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Oh! heavens!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Florio! then my fears were true.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Can I truſt my ſenſes?

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: I think not, we are aſleep, and dreaming, or haunted by fairies.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How is it poſſible I find you here? Did not my noble friend undertake your protection?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: So did he yours, yet you are here, and equally expos'd to ruin.—Oh! how I grieve to ſay, 'tis he that has betray'd us both!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Antonio betray us!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Oh! no.—

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: It is, too ſurely—he is the man, to whom my brother has contracted me.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p:
Bleſs my ſtars! no wonder we have blunder'd ſo, when we contriv'd to take a huſband into
our party; nothing can ſucceed, they are concern'd in.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Contracted to Honoria! he come to marry my Honoria.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: The very ſame, and he has taken theſe ungenerous means, to ſacrifice us both.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I will not, cannot think it; I would as ſoon believe impoſſibilities, as his apoſtacy from honour.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What's her concern in him Honoria?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: That adds to our diſtreſſes—ſhe, and Antonio—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: This is no time to relate adventures—Florio and you muſt not be found here; therefore, Roſa, take this key, and ſet open the garden door, that leads to St. Jerome's ſtreet, thro' that you may eaſily eſcape, on the leaſt alarm.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Make haſte, dear girl.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Generous Felicia!

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: My lovely girl, under what obligations—how now Roſa! What's the matter?—

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: Undone paſt hope! your brother, Antonio, Juan, and ſervants, with ſwords drawn, are, at this inſtant, in the hall: what will you do?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Into this inner room; retire, my love, and let me meet their rage.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I cannot leave you—let me but ſtay, and ſhare your fate—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I have no fears, but for you; nay haſte; I muſt compel you to the only means of ſafety, and concealment.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Oh! if that's your ſcheme, the devil take the hindmoſt! 'tis for your ſake, Roſa, I ſhun theſe honourable engagements;—having loſt my weapon, the beſt, I can do, is to walk off with the baggage.
sp.stage: Enter HENRIQUEZ, JUAN, ANTONIO, JAQUES, and GERALDO, with Lights.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I will not be perſuaded.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Couſin, you muſt: I have an honour too to guard, dear to me as yours is to you; in all, that juſtice ſanctifies, will I tread ſtep for ſtep; but will not permit my houſe to be the ſcene of premeditated miſchief, and revenge;—already they have ſtain'd theſe walls too deeply.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Such admonitions are too ſacred, ſurely, to paſs unregarded; Henriquez cannot be ſo loſt—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I cannot be ſo loſt to my own honour's calls, or nature's feeling, to liſten to a cynic's cold advice. Where is the man whoſe inſolence and folly has ſo far miſled him—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Here is the man you ſeek.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What do I ſee:

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Whom thou ſo baſely haſt betray'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My friend! my Florio!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No more thy friend, Antonio, but Florio, by thy perfidy betray'd, and thrown upon his fate—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Let me paſs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hold a moment!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What mean you? Is all your fervour in a brother's intereſt reduc'd to a mean parley with the foe? I'll right myſelf.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Couſin forbear; you ſhall not have your way; there lies ſome myſtery conceal'd in this, which once unfolded, might perhaps reconcile the difference.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p:
It cannot be but by the ſword; Antonio, hear me; if that the faith and friendſhip pledg'd to me want power to rouze you, let your own intereſt
and honour; that man, whom you protect from my reſentment, has ſeconded his inſolence to me, by foul attempts upon Honoria's honour.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I ſeek to wrong her honour! the parent of your black deſigns, and bitter enmity, ne'er yet invented a more helliſh ſalſhood; 'tis true, I have lov'd the virtuous Honoria—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How, ſir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: But with ſuch ſpotleſs affection, ſuch pure devotion, that ſhe has recompenc'd my paſſion with eſteem; has chain'd me to her ſervice, and I will either live to call her mine, or periſh in her cauſe.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Diſtraction—daggers to my heart!—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Oh! has it rous'd you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Henriquez pauſe!—mitigate your fury for a moment.—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I will not—His life or mine muſt pay the inſolence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hold, or thro' me you paſs; I muſt be heard. That impious man from infancy have I call'd friend;—allow me but a minute's ſpace, alone to queſtion him about our mutual wrongs—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Antonio, do not trifle with me; mean you to let him eſcape?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, by name and honour; if I deal not in this buſineſs to your heart's wiſh, and honour's credit, my own life ſhall pay the forfeit.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Conſent, Henriquez, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My heart is bleeding, while I ſpeak—I am not us'd to ſue; let me conjure you by your hopes of bliſs, by all your deareſt wiſhes, by our propos'd union, grant me this, or here our friendſhip ceaſes, and we meet no more.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Delay is agony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will not keep you long.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What means Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dareſt thou anſwer my demands?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I can, and juſtify myſelf, thou traitor to thy friend!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lead to ſome other ſpot.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: This way, good couſin.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I will not long be dallied with; theſe keen ſenſations will not leave my heart, nor can my fury die.
sp.stage: Enter HONORIA, FELICIA, and ROSA—GUZMAN following.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I am frighted to death.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: At all events, let's follow, and ſee the reſult.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: Let me go firſt, ladies, and watch their motions, I'll keep an excellent look-out, and alarm you, in caſe of extremity.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Be it ſo then; away!

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: There will be miſchief ſoon.—Therefore, as my maſter has rudely left the ladies, the leaſt I can do is to keep with 'em, and take care of 'em.
sp.stage: Scene changes to the Hall of Don JUAN's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Give up my title! I never will renounce Honoria.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You muſt—ſhe is ſo much mine, that none muſt boaſt pretenſions to her, while I live—in ſaving you from mad Henriquez' ſword, I have diſcharg'd the engagement friendſhip made; the injur'd huſband now requires his dues.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Spite of my wrongs, I know not how to lift my ſword againſt the breaſt of him, who has given me ſuch juſt, ſuch ſtrong, and ſuch repeated reaſons, to admire, and love him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It was Florio, my comrade in arms, my boſom-friend, whom I deſign'd to ſerve; not that diſloyal man, who has invaded my honour, and my love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Mean, treacherous artifice! to do ſo groſs an injury yourſelf, then charge me as the wronger! I ſwear, by all thoſe powers, who both diſcern, and puniſh, I never knew that you pretended to Henriquez' ſiſter, till ſince I came within theſe fatal walls.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How am I to believe you can ſpeak truth in this, who have myſelf been witneſs of your falſhood to her?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I falſe to Honoria! take heed, Antonio, ſo foul an injury I cannot brook.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Rare confidence! have I not myſelf aſſiſted your feign'd paſſion, and been witneſs of your faithleſs vows pledg'd to another?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Another! what mean device has bred ſo ſtrange a charge? but dars't thou talk of violated truth? where are thoſe ardent, ſacred, and eternal vows, pledg'd to an unknown fair, with which, at our firſt interview this night, thou did'ſt abuſe my credulous ear, and taught my ſympathiſing heart, torn as it was with it's own griefs, to throb with pangs for thee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Still written here;—baſe man, I cannot longer bear thy mean evaſions; either renounce all claim to Honoria, or this muſt ſpeak the reſt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'll be reduc'd to atoms, ere I yield her.
sp.stage: Enter HENRIQUEZ, JUAN, and the reſt.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Ay this is well—he ſhall not 'ſcape, without ſome marks of my revenge.
sp.stage: Florio, Antonio turns in his Defence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hold ſir; he ſhall not be o'erpower'd with numbers neither; my honour you invade anew, and wake my pre-engagement to protect him.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Flames and the devil! why were not you yourſelf doing your beſt to kill him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis true; but if he muſt fall, he ſhall not be maſſacred by odds, but conquer'd fairly like a man.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, ceaſe this violence; I'll dye for't, but ſome curſed error lies conceal'd, that thus miſleads us all.—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: With my ſword alone I'll ſearch it out, tho' multitudes oppos'd me.
sp.stage: [He attacks again, Roſa peeping at the door, cries out Ladies! Ladies!
Enter HONORIA, FELICIA, and ROSA running.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Hear us! hear us!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: By heavens, Honoria!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Why did not I tell you ſhe was brought here by my direction?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Oh! thou vile woman! that I cou'd deſtroy thy memory with thy life!
sp.stage: [He advances furiouſly towards Honoria; Antonio, Juan, and Florio interpoſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hold, ſir;—altho' I do not know this lady, I have, this night, engag'd my faith both to protect, and ſerve her.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: See there! he does not know Honoria.—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Not know her! why 'tis not an hour, ſince I ſaw him entertaining her at my houſe; death! all we ſee is illuſion, and all we do inchantment!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Suffer me, Don Henriquez, to unſpel theſe charms—Antonio, which of us is it, you pretend to?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Which? how can you aſk? you know too well the conqueſt, which you made of my poor heart, in Flanders.—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Conqueſt! heart! and Flanders? what means that now?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: More riddles every moment!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Your contract with Honoria then—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here I confirm it—when I forego ſo dear a tye, or wed another fair—

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Take heed, for I am not Honoria.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not Honoria!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is't poſſible? have I been only mock'd with viſionary bliſs, and are my hopes thus blaſted?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: All now depends on whatſoever turn Henriquez' temper takes—Obſerve his conduct, nor doubt of mine.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment, and diſappointed fury ſeem to poſſeſs my brother's thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I'll try to calm them.—Know, Don Henriquez, that Don Florio has ever been your ſiſter's conſtant lover, his private viſits, at our houſe, which have diſturb'd your peace, were by me calculated for their interview, after you had refus'd her to his addreſſes;—my heart was then entirely free; 'tis now engag'd:—if I treſpaſs too far on that reſerve, which is our ſex's ornament, and guard, let the preſent exigence, and my gratitude for ſignal ſervices, plead my excuſe, while I declare, it is to that brave officer.—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: This, brother, is that generous commander, whoſe valiant arm reſtor'd our liberties, and who engag'd himſelf the guardian of my honour.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: This that gallant leader, to whom we are ſo much indebted?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Why did you not inform me ſooner of ſo laudable a prepoſſeſſion?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My dear brother, gratitude, eſteem, and a thouſand nameleſs paſſions, ſo ſoon poſſeſs'd me, I was aſham'd of what you might have call'd a viſionary love, and durſt not truſt my own tongue with my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Your ſiſter, and this lady, Don Henriquez, both can witneſs I never had a thought to injure your happineſs, or honour. Don Pedro's death was occaſion'd by your miſtaken jealouſy; and you well know, (but that your ſelf, and your domeſticks, were the only witneſſes of that tranſaction) I had the faireſt claim to the protection of the law, having been ſurpris'd at diſ-advantage and oppreſs'd by numbers.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pedro deſerv'd his death, and I am blameleſs.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: My ſhame! my eternal ſhame! what ſhall I ſay? you ſee me overwhelm'd with confuſion; if I have acted in a manner unbecoming my name, and honour, attribute it to love—(I ſeek not longer to conceal it,) a hurt, a deſperate, jealous love for that ungrateful creature.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p:
Couſin, I will now own, I have perceiv'd it long; and in juſtice to our friendſhip, and alliance, have even addreſs'd my ſiſter on the ſubject; but found ſuch inſurmountable objections to your but
violence of temper, that, in conſideration of what your pride might ſuffer, I conceal'd my knowledge of your paſſion, even from yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: How cou'd a man of Don Henriquez' ſenſe, and penetration, ſuppoſe his tyrannic treatment of ſo amiable a ſiſter, ſuch everlaſting doubts, ſuſpicions, jealouſies, reſtrictions, and ſeverities, muſt not diſguſt rather than win a woman's heart? Cou'd you but have ſubdued thoſe paſſions, perhaps, ere I had ſeen that gentleman, I might have been induc'd to think of you in ſuch a light, as your perſon, and natural endowments deſerv'd; if a diſappointment herein be painful, to your ſelf alone you are indebted for it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Forbear, I pray you; ſhew not the happineſs I might have reached, nor add the weight of your reproaches, to my ſelf-condemnation; my puniſhment is ſufficient without it;—I have juſtly railed; when ſuch a heart as mine concedes, the pangs it ſuffers are not trivial.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I am ſorry, and aſk pardon.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Yet to convince you that my ſorrow is not ſelfiſh; as I have been the ſource of general uneaſineſs, I will endeavour to make a general amends, let my own heart ſuffer what it may: firſt madam, may you enjoy more happineſs, if poſſible, than I have wiſh'd to partake with you; and, ſir, to you, unaſk'd I thus reſign this contract, which love and juſtice both forbid me now to claim,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Noble Henriquez; I thank and honour you.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Sir, take from me her hand, whoſe heart your worth, and bravery has merited.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Thus I receive the ſum of happineſs, this world can give; and, ſir, ſince you have generouſly reſign'd the name of brother, allow me that of friend, which while I live I will deſerve; and ſuffer
me to entreat your concurrence for your ſiſter's happineſs, where deſtiny ſeems to lead;—I will anſwer, with my life, my friend will merit her.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe is your's;—and here dies all my animoſity.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We are now all your debtors; I am peculiarly ſo.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: My brother, now you are indeed my brother; noble, generous, and kind, you have ſet my heart at eaſe, and I am myſelf again.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: That's more than I am, I'm ſure; I have ſeen ſo many wonders, I ſhan't be myſelf again this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: They have had a rare come-off; ſure, 'twou'd make a good plot for a play.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: That wou'd be bad for me; for, by the laws of comedy, I ſhould be oblig'd to marry you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well thought of, Guzman, tho' ſpoke in jeſt; you ſeem well fitted for each other, and your faithful ſervices deſerve our general encouragement; what ſay you Roſa?

sp.speaker: Roſa.
sp.p: Sir, I ſay I have had ſo many frights to night, I am e'en afraid to lye alone.

sp.speaker: Guz.
sp.p: Thy hand, ſweet Roſa; 'tis a bargain; if I dont repent firſt, I don't care.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: This union being in my houſe, let me entreat your ſtay, to unite in woad'ring at theſe events, and enjoying general congratulations; couſin you will not refuſe me?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p:
I will not be a means to thwart your mirth, but endeavour, as well as I am able, to partake it,—my heart has now a new, a difficult, and painful leſſon ſet it, but it muſt be learn'd; for our adventures prove that womens mild and gentle hearts muſt be ſooth'd by indulgence, not frighted
by ſeverity; and that eaſy, frank, and confiding tempers bid faireſt for a generous return,

q.l: Since ſuch, and ſuch alone, deſerve to ſhare
The confidence, and favour of the fair.

lg.l: AY!—ay!—they're at it—in a dainty tew;
"Have you the Epilogue?"—"Not I—" have you?
(Miſs Macklin and Miſs Wilford there I mean)
"I!—I don't know that any has been ſeen".
"Lud! where's the author?—I'm in ſuch a fright!
"The author, child?—not ventur'd here to-night."
"What ſhall we do, my dear?"—"I cannot gueſs"—
To palliate this ridiculous diſtreſs,
Will you permit me to apologize
For this hard tax on new form'd comedies?—
In ſhort theſe Epilogues are grown ſo trite,
So few the ſubjects left, whereon to write,
So few the authors with this knack endued,
Perhaps my nonſenſe may be quite as good.
I've been in front—and, if with leave I may,
I'll give my inferences from this play.
See Mr. Garrick's Epilogue to the Earl of Warwick. The beauteous Marg'ret of the Rival-Houſe,
To lower the grandeur of deſpotic ſpouſe,
Has taught the ladies, in true comic vein,
Rules to maintain, and uſe, their pow'r o'er men.
My hints (altho' in homelier ſtyle than thoſe)
To you, ye Lords of Nature, I'll diſcloſe.
Would you, high Potentates, throughout your lives,
Preſerve obedient ſiſters, daughters, wives,
Avoid Henriquez' faults—be never proud,
Diſtruſtful, jealous, arrogant, or loud;
Where e'er we go, what e'er we do, or ſay,
Make it your rule—to give us our own way;
Neither attempt to lead us, nor reſtrain,
But let us have the length of all the rein;
In ſhoppings, auctions, jauntings, or Quadrille,
Leave us to ſpend, and loſe what e'er we will;
Let all our fav'rite foibles take their courſe,
(For every breather has ſome hobby-horſe)
With whatſoever whims or freaks you meet,
Still let your words and looks alike be ſweet—
Lord! when thus left to our own tempers free,
The ſweeteſt creatures in the world are we!—
Hence this important Maxim is defin'd,
Ye wiſe ones, keep it ever in your mind—
We women never frown, if never teaz'd,
And, always humour'd,—we are always pleaſ'd.
